title: Massive new study links pollution to assaults and domestic violence
text:
A massive study of daily air quality across nearly 400 U.S. counties finds a direct connection between dirtier air and higher rates of violent crime, including assault and domestic violence.

The effects show up even below current U.S. environmental standards, suggesting that further tightening those standards could reduce the level of crime and make people safer, according to the peer-reviewed study set to be published in the Journal of Environmental Economics and Management.

“We find a robust positive effect of increased air pollution on violent crimes, and specifically assaults,” write the researchers from Colorado State University and the University of Minnesota. “The results suggest that a 10% reduction in daily [pollutants] and ozone could save $1.4 billion in crime costs a year.”

Researchers used eight years’ of data — from 2006 to 2013 — on crime rates, pollution, wildfire smoke and weather to calculate the correlations. These included crime data from the Federal Bureau of Investigations’ National Incident Based Reporting System; pollution data from the Environmental Protection Agency’s Air Quality System network of monitors and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Hazard Mapping System; and weather data from Oregon State University’s PRISM Climate Group.

The air quality was measured for the amount of PM 2.5, meaning pollutant particles smaller than 2.5 micrometers, and ozone, a gas formed when sunlight reacts with pollutants emitted by various sources including factories, power plants and cars.

One caveat: The study looked only at counties where daily data could be found or reliably calculated. This constituted a very broad sample — 397 counties, covering 28% of the U.S. population — but by no means all of the country, and no counties in, say, New York or California.

The researchers were able to compare short-term, and even daily, changes in pollution by county with the incidence of crime.

“A 10% increase in same-day exposure to PM 2.5 is associated with an 0.14% increase in crimes, nearly all of which is driven by increases in assaults, which are indicative of aggressive behavior,” the researchers found. “A 10% increase in same-day exposure to ozone is associated with a 0.3% increase in violent crime or a 0.35% increase in assaults.”

Pollution outside drives violence both inside and outside the home, they add. “[C]hanges in outdoor PM 2.5 and ozone affect indoor behavior, and in particular, likely impact domestic violence,” they wrote.

The effects were greater at low temperatures, they said. And they kicked in well below the EPA’s current air quality standards.

The direct causes of this are not fully known, they said. The irritation from pollution causes “systemic inflammation” and “cellular oxidative stress,” they noted — but the mechanisms are “not well understood,” they added, and they couldn’t directly identify the physiological pathways behind their results.

The data show a rise in violent crimes, including those driven by impulsive behavior, but not a rise in property crimes, they said.

This study is far from the first to find a link between air quality and other social outcomes. Perhaps the most notable study has been the so-called lead crime hypothesis, which argues that the surge in crime rates in U.S. cities from the 1960s to the early 1990s was a result of children growing up breathing lead from car exhausts.

The crime rates apparently surged about 20 years after car exhausts took off in the 1940s, and started falling about 20 years after the introduction of unleaded gasoline in the 1970s. Lead is known to have harmful effects on children. The hypothesis, however, is not without its critics.

The latest study also follows a paper published last year by the Institute of Labor Economics that found “elevated levels of air pollution have a positive and statistically significant impact on overall crime,” with stronger effects found for less-severe crimes. A study three years ago by Britain’s Spatial Economics Research Center found a link between air quality and poverty dating back to the industrial revolution.

Other researchers last year published findings connecting pollution and crime rates, arguing that dirtier air raised anxiety levels.
